I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to  the  Islamic  Republic of  Afghanistan for  the  Emergency  Assistance for  COVID-19  Pandemic 
Response.  The  emergency  assistance  will  (i)  rehabilitate  or  construct  hospitals  and  medical 
facilities  in  the  most  affected  areas,  (ii)  procure  medicines  and  medical  equipment,  and  (iii) 
support capacity building and resilience strengthening of the national health system to respond to 
public health emergencies including coronavirus disease (COVID-19). 
 
In line with the National Emergency Response Plan for Coronavirus 2020 (NERP)1 and 
2. 
the  fragile  and  conflict-affected  situations  (FCAS)  approach  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank 
(ADB), the emergency assistance will support the Government of Afghanistan in its response to 
the COVID-19 pandemic.2 The proposed emergency assistance responds to the government’s 
request  to  ADB  made  on  16  March  2020  for  emergency  response  and  resilience  building  for 
COVID-19.3 
 

II. 

THE EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
COVID-19  has  spread  rapidly  and  the  World  Health  Organization  (WHO)  declared  it  a 
3. 
global pandemic on 11 March 2020. More than 3.34 million individuals have tested positive and it 
has caused an estimated 238,380 deaths globally (as of 2 May 2020).4 In many countries, the 
actual number of infected people is difficult to estimate, given low testing capacity and rates. The 
rate of the infection depends on a country’s initial response; social distancing measures; the risk 
profile of the population; and the resources used to undertake surveillance and testing, and to 
provide  health  services.  These  factors  greatly  influence  the  number  of  COVID-19  infected 
persons, death rates, and recovery time.   
 
4. 
Afghanistan is a landlocked country bordering Iran; the People’s Republic of China (PRC); 
Pakistan; and the Central Asian Republics of Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan. It is an 
integral part of the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) Program.5 Regional 
connectivity is vital for trade, transit, and Afghan employment in the region and remittances to the 
country. The two neighboring countries that have had major COVID-19 epidemics are the PRC 
and  Iran,  both  of  which  have  people  and  trade  linkages  with  Afghanistan.  The  spread  in  Iran 
continues  at  an  alarming  rate,  with  90,500 cases  and  5,710 deaths  officially  reported  as  of  26 
April 2020.6 Pakistan has also witnessed a rapid increase in the number of cases and deaths.

 The vulnerability of migrants returning from Iran and Pakistan is one of the biggest challenges 
facing  Afghanistan. More  than  240,000  Afghans  returned from Iran from  1  January  to  11  April 
2020, while 70,000 returned from Pakistan from 6 to 9 April 2020.7 These returning Afghans travel 
across the country, often returning to their home provinces. 
 
5. 
Afghanistan  is  facing  a  COVID-19  emergency.  Given  the  extremely  limited  border 
surveillance and testing capacity, minimal early COVID-19 detection and isolation takes place. 
Given the number of returnees and the nature of the virus, community transmission is likely to 
happen at scale, potentially leading to a large number of infected people. In addition, while health 
sector service delivery has improved over the last 15 years, it lacks the capacity to respond to the 
COVID-19. The situation is complicated given the insecurity, political uncertainty and poverty.8 
 

1. 

COVID-19 Emergency Situation  

   
6. 
Afghanistan is in the early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic—its first reported case was 
confirmed on 22 February 2020 and it had 2,335 confirmed cases and 68 reported deaths as of 
2  May  2020,  with  the  number  of  cases  rapidly  increasing.9  COVID-19  is  a  public  health 
emergency,  which  is  aggravated  by  the  country’s  constrained  health  sector  infrastructure  and 
capacity  to:  (i)  respond  adequately  to  the  expected  scale  of  the  epidemic,  (ii)  provide  basic 
services to restrict the spread of COVID-19, and (iii) deliver essential treatment services to the 
population. The country has 10,400 public hospital beds, of which only 991 have been allocated 
to treat COVID-19 patients (footnote 1). The testing for COVID-19 remains very limited. To scale 
up testing efforts, WHO has supported the government to establish eight testing facilities which 
are able to process an average of 100-150 tests in each laboratory  per day.10 The government 
recognized the public health risks and initiated lockdown measures in various parts of the country. 
 
7. 
COVID-19  will  result  in  severe  social  and  economic  dislocation.  Analysis  by  the 
International Monetary Fund (IMF) forecast that the COVID-19 pandemic will significantly affect 
the country’s economic prospects for 2020—increasing unemployment; and reducing remittance 
inflows, regional trade, government revenue, and overall economic activity.11 It will significantly 
affect household employment levels and livelihoods, threaten food security, and increase poverty 
rates  (estimated  at  55%  in  2017).12  Analysis  by  the  Biruni  Institute  estimated  that  8  million 
additional people could be at risk of falling below the poverty line if economic crisis materializes 
in  2020.13  More  detailed  analysis  is  presented  in  the  Summary  Assessment  of  Damage  and 
Needs.14 
 

2.

with  relevant  ministries  and  agencies  (footnote  1).  The  NERP  incorporates  the  COVID-19 
preparedness and response plans of WHO and the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF). 
The  plan  aims  to  address  the  evolving  demands  of  COVID-19.  It  includes  a  strategy  to  target

9. 
The NERP provides the framework for coordinated support of each core element and has 
identified key development partners to provide this funding. The indicative costings of the plan 
are based on three scenarios for different rates of infection. At this stage, the most relevant is the 
intermediate  scenario  (with  social  distancing),  resulting  in  190,000  infected  persons  with  an 
indicative  cost  for  response  of  $323  million.  Given  the  government’s  tight  fiscal  space  for 
budgetary  resources,  and  dependence  on  development  partners  for  the  operating  and 
development budget, the planned funding is largely dependent on development partner support. 
The Ministry of Finance (MOF) has allocated an initial $25 million for critical medical supplies; and 
hospital infrastructure in Herat and Nimruz provinces, near the border with Iran.15 
 
10. 
As part of this coordinated support, on 16 March 2020 the government requested ADB to 
provide $40 million emergency assistance to prepare for and respond to the COVID-19 pandemic 
to  strengthen  the  national  public  health  response;  build  resilience;  rehabilitate  and  construct 
hospitals and medical facilities in the most vulnerable provinces; and procure medical equipment, 
supplies,  and  medicines.  The  support  requested  covers  improving  COVID-19  hospital  patient 
assessment,  management,  and  treatment  by  focusing  on  critical  hospital  medical  facility 
infrastructure  (isolation  wards  and  intensive  care  units);  medical  equipment  and  supplies;  and 
capacity  development  and  resilience.  This  was  identified  as  a  critical  gap.  The  health  sector 
development  partners  will  undertake  the  earlier  stages  of  initial  infection  identification  at  local 
clinics, as well as COVID-19 public awareness, testing, and assessment, under new or existing 
national programs that will be expanded.

Development Partner Coordination  

 
11.

development  partners  to  ensure  close  coordination  of  the  COVID-19  priority  support. 
Afghanistan’s  health  sector,  led  by  the  MOPH,  has  been  working  mainly  with  the  Afghanistan 
Reconstruction Trust Fund development partners and the World Bank, WHO, UNICEF, and the 
European Union.16  These development partners are expanding their engagement, and in some 
cases repurposing their programs to cover COVID-19 related interventions. The government has 
established  a  High-Level  Emergency  Coordination  Committee,  with  various  technical  working 
groups. The Afghanistan President is guiding COVID-19 support and responses, and the second 
Vice-President chairs and coordinates the high-level committee.  
 
12.

systems  and  expertise  to  fast-track  procurement  and  implementation.  In  consultation  with  the

wider economic and social impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic, including food security, poverty,

Other development partners, such as the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), are

15.

government.  In  line  with  its  comprehensive  response  to  the  COVID-19  pandemic,  ADB  will

Output 1: Hospitals and medical facilities rehabilitated or constructed. This output 
17. 
will support the construction of hospitals on existing hospital land that is owned by the MOPH or 
the  government,  comprising  isolation  wards  and  intensive  care  units.  It  will  also  include  the 
rehabilitation of medical facilities following the “build back better” principle.25 In coordination with 
the UN agencies, the government has formulated a list of high-priority provinces to be targeted. 
In line with this list, the emergency assistance will support the rehabilitation of five hospitals and 
medical facilities and the construction of 10 hospitals using prefabricated technology (about 750 
new hospital beds) under Phase 1 and construction of an additional five hospitals (about 400 new 
hospital beds) under Phase 2. The medical facilities will comply with international isolation ward 
standards  and  will  include  utilities  such  as  energy-efficient  power  generators,  including,  where 
appropriate, solar power; water, sanitation, and hygiene corners; standard ventilation and heating 
systems; and waste management systems.26 The new facilities will be constructed and equipped 
to ensure continued use after COVID-19. Afghanistan has 0.5 hospital beds per 1,000 population, 
which is below the regional average.27 Most hospitals have no critical care beds. The government 
has committed to ensure long-term sustainability and appropriate staffing of these facilities. These 
facilities  will  be  women-friendly  and  culturally  sensitive,  and  help  address  issues  related  to 
maternal and child health in the longer term, including access to services.   
  
18. 
Output  2:  Medicines  and  medical  equipment  supplied.  This  output  will  support  and 
strengthen the procurement of medical equipment, furniture, supplies, and quality medicines to 
ensure  that  the  new  medical  facilities  created  under  output  1  are  fully  operational.  It  will  also 
provide  support  for  the  government  response  to  COVID-19  through  procurement  of  urgent 
medicines, medical equipment, and supplies. The items will be procured following a list prepared 
by the MOPH, which is based on the WHO recommended list. The list of medicines and equipment 
has been discussed with other development partners, including the World Bank and UN agencies,

supplies, and medicines to treat the affected population; and support capacity building efforts to 
respond to the crisis more effectively. These efforts will contribute to a reduction in the loss of life,

47. 
The emergency assistance is categorized effective gender mainstreaming. It will support 
facilities that are sensitive to gender and culture, such as dedicated wards for female patients and 
separate office and lounge facilities for women doctors and nurses. The facilities will have all the 
equipment to treat critical care patients with COVID-19 and other infectious diseases, including 
infected pregnant women, infected women delivering their babies, and their newborn babies. In 
the long term, these rehabilitated medical facilities are expected to improve access to maternal 
and child health services. While all medical personnel will be provided with appropriate and well-
fitting protective equipment, female staff will also receive menstrual kits as needed. Training on 
COVID-19 treatment and surveillance will be provided to all medical staff, including women staff. 
Other  medical  support  staff,  including  female  staff,  will  also  be  provided  with  the  necessary 
training. Finally, the project will develop a gender-sensitive resilience strategy which will include 
improved access for women to sexual and reproductive health services, and support mechanisms 
for gender-based violence.
